008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.corners;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.EPSILON_DOUBLE;
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.isZero;
013import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
014import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.add;
015import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.distL2;
016import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.dotProduct;
017import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
018import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.normL2;
019
020/**
021 * <p>
022 * Common interface for all sub-pixel maximum locator implementations.
023 * A  sub-pixel maximum locator tries to interpolate the continuous position
024 * and value of a local maximum for a discrete 3x3 neighborhood.
025 * The center value in the discrete neighborhood is assumed to be a local maximum.
026 * See Sec. 6.5 and Appendix E of [1] for additional details.
027 * </p>
028 * <p>
029 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>,
030 * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
031 * </p>
032 * 
033 * @see QuadraticTaylor
034 * @see QuadraticLeastSquares
035 * @see Quartic
036 * @author WB
037 * @version 2021/01/19
038 * @version 2022/09/11 revised instance creation
039 */
040public abstract class SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
041        
042        private SubpixelMaxInterpolator() {}
043        
044        /**
045         * Tries to locate the sub-pixel maximum from the 9 discrete sample values
046         * (s0,...,s8) taken from a 3x3 neighborhood, arranged in the following order:
047         * <pre>
048         * s4 s3 s2
049         * s5 s0 s1
050         * s6 s7 s8
051         * </pre>
052         * The center value (s0) is associated with position (0,0).
053         * 
054         * @param s a vector containing 9 sample values in the order described above
055         * @return a 3-element array [x,y,z], with the estimated maximum position (x,y) 
056         * and the associated max. value (z). 
057         * The position is relative to the center coordinate (0,0).
058         * {@code null} is returned if the maximum position could not be located.
059         */
060        public abstract float[] getMax(float[] s);
061        
062        /**
063         * Enumeration of different {@link SubpixelMaxInterpolator} methods.
064         */
065        public enum Method {
066                /** Second-order (quadratic) Taylor interpolation */
067                QuadraticTaylor(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.QuadraticTaylor.getInstance()),
068                
069                /** Second-order (quadratic) least-squares interpolation" */
070                QuadraticLeastSquares(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.QuadraticLeastSquares.getInstance()),
071                
072                /** Quartic interpolation */ 
073                Quartic(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.Quartic.getInstance()),
074                
075                /** No interpolation */
076                None(null);
077                
078                private final SubpixelMaxInterpolator inst;
079                
080                private Method(SubpixelMaxInterpolator instance) {
081                        this.inst = instance;
082                }
083                
084                public SubpixelMaxInterpolator getInstance() {
085                        return this.inst;
086                }
087        }
088        
089        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
090        
091        /**
092         * <p>
093         * 2D interpolator using second-order Taylor expansion to find the coefficients
094         * of the quadratic interpolating polynomial 
095         * </p>
096         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
097         * <p>
098         * The resulting function fits exactly the 5 on-axis samples 
099         * (s[0], s[1], s[3], s[5], s[7]) but in general does not pass
100         * through the outer diagonal samples (s[2], s[4], s[6], s[8]).
101         * See Appendix E.2.2 (Alg. E.1, 'FindMaxQuadraticTaylor') of [1] for 
102         * additional details.
103         * </p>
104         * <p>
105         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>,
106         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
107         * </p>
108         */
109        public static class QuadraticTaylor extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
110                
111                private static final QuadraticTaylor instance = new QuadraticTaylor();
112                private QuadraticTaylor() {};
113                public static QuadraticTaylor getInstance() {
114                        return instance;
115                }
116                
117                private final double[] c = new double[6];       // polynomial coefficients
118
119                @Override
120                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
121                        c[0] = s[0];
122                        c[1] = (s[1] - s[5]) / 2;
123                        c[2] = (s[7] - s[3]) / 2;
124                        c[3] = (s[1] - 2*s[0] + s[5]) / 2;
125                        c[4] = (s[3] - 2*s[0] + s[7]) / 2;
126                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
127                        
128                        double d = (4*c[3]*c[4] - sqr(c[5]));   // determinant of Hessian
129                        
130                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || c[3] >= 0) {  // undefined or not a maximum
131                                return null;
132                        }
133                        
134                        // max position:
135                        float x = (float) ((c[2]*c[5] - 2*c[1]*c[4]) / d);
136                        float y = (float) ((c[1]*c[5] - 2*c[2]*c[3]) / d);
137                        // max value:
138                        float z = (float) (c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y + c[5]*x*y);
139                        return new float[] {x, y, z};
140                }
141        }
142        
143        /**
144         * 2D interpolator using second-order Taylor expansion to find the coefficients
145         * of the quadratic interpolating polynomial 
146         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
147         * The resulting function fits exactly the 5 on-axis samples 
148         * (s[0], s[1], s[3], s[5], s[7]) but in general does not pass
149         * through the outer diagonal samples (s[2], s[4], s[6], s[8]).
150         * Alternate version using explicit inverse Hessian.
151         */
152        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
153        private static class QuadraticTaylorAlt extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
154                
155                private static final QuadraticTaylorAlt instance = new QuadraticTaylorAlt();
156                private QuadraticTaylorAlt() {};
157                public static QuadraticTaylorAlt getInstance() {
158                        return instance;
159                }
160
161                @Override
162                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
163                        double[] g = {                                                  // the gradient
164                                        (s[1] - s[5]) / 2, 
165                                        (s[7] - s[3]) / 2};     
166                        
167                        double H00 = s[1] - 2*s[0] + s[5];              // elements of the Hessian matrix
168                        double H11 = s[3] - 2*s[0] + s[7];
169                        double H01 = (s[4] + s[8] - s[2] - s[6]) / 4;                   
170                        double d = H00 * H11 - sqr(H01);                // = det(H)
171                        
172                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || H00 >= 0) {   // not a maximum (minimum or saddle point)
173                                return null;
174                        }
175                        
176                        double[][] Hi = {                       // inverse Hessian
177                                        { H11 / d, -H01 / d}, 
178                                        {-H01 / d,  H00 / d}};  
179                        
180                        double[] delta = multiply(Hi, g);
181                        double[] xy = multiply(-1, delta);                              // maximum position
182                        double q = s[0] - 0.5 * dotProduct(g, delta);   // maximum value
183                        return new float[] {(float) xy[0], (float) xy[1], (float) q};
184                }
185        }
186        
187        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
188        
189        /**
190         * <p>
191         * 2D interpolator based on least-squares fitting a quadratic polynomial 
192         * </p>
193         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
194         * <p>to the supplied sample values.
195         * See Sec. E.2.3 (Alg. E2, 'FindMaxQuadraticLeastSquares') of [1] for
196         * additional details.
197         * </p>
198         * <p>
199         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>,
200         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
201         * </p>
202         */
203        public static class QuadraticLeastSquares extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
204                
205                private static final QuadraticLeastSquares instance = new QuadraticLeastSquares();
206                private QuadraticLeastSquares() {};
207                public static QuadraticLeastSquares getInstance() {
208                        return instance;
209                }
210                
211                private final double[] c = new double[6];       // polynomial coefficients
212
213                @Override
214                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
215                        c[0] = (5 * s[0] + 2 * s[1] - s[2] + 2 * s[3] - s[4] + 2 * s[5] - s[6] + 2 * s[7] - s[8]) / 9;
216                        c[1] = (s[1] + s[2] - s[4] - s[5] - s[6] + s[8]) / 6;
217                        c[2] = (-s[2] - s[3] - s[4] + s[6] + s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
218                        c[3] = (-2 * s[0] + s[1] + s[2] - 2 * s[3] + s[4] + s[5] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
219                        c[4] = (-2 * s[0] - 2 * s[1] + s[2] + s[3] + s[4] - 2 * s[5] + s[6] + s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
220                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
221                        
222                        double d = (4*c[3]*c[4] - sqr(c[5]));
223                        
224                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || c[3] >= 0) {  // not a maximum (minimum or saddle point)
225                                return null;
226                        }
227                        
228                        // max position:
229                        float x = (float) ((c[2]*c[5] - 2*c[1]*c[4]) / d);
230                        float y = (float) ((c[1]*c[5] - 2*c[2]*c[3]) / d);
231                        // max value:
232                        float z = (float) (c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y + c[5]*x*y);
233                        return new float[] {x, y, z};
234                }
235        }
236        
237        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
238        
239        /**
240         * <p>
241         * 2D interpolator based on fitting a 'quartic' (i.e., 4th-order) polynomial
242         * </p>
243         * <pre>
244         * f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2 + c_5 x y + c_6 x^2 y + c_7 x y^2 + c_8 x^2 y^2</pre>
245         * <p>
246         * to the supplied sample values. The interpolation function passes through
247         * all sample values. The local maximum cannot be found in closed form but 
248         * is found iteratively, which is not guaranteed to succeed.
249         * See Appendix E.2.4 (Alg. E.3, 'FindMaxQuartic') of [1] for 
250         * additional details.
251         * </p>
252         * <p>
253         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>,
254         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
255         * </p>
256         */
257        public static class Quartic extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
258                public static final int DefaultMaxIterations = 20;      // iteration limit
259                public static final double DefaulMaxDelta = 1e-6;       // smallest x/y move to continue search 
260                public static final double DefaultMaxRad = 1.0;         // x/y search boundary (-xyLimit, +xyLimit)
261                
262                private final int maxIterations;
263                private final double maxDelta;
264                private final double maxRad;
265                
266                private final double[] c = new double[9];       // polynomial coefficients
267                
268                private static final Quartic instance = new Quartic();
269                
270                private Quartic() {
271                        this(DefaultMaxIterations, DefaulMaxDelta, DefaultMaxRad);
272                }
273                
274                private Quartic(int maxIterations, double maxDelta, double maxRad) {
275                        this.maxIterations = maxIterations;
276                        this.maxDelta = maxDelta;
277                        this.maxRad = maxRad;
278                }
279                
280                public static Quartic getInstance() {
281                        return instance;
282                }
283                
284                public static Quartic getInstance(int maxIterations, double maxDelta, double maxRad) {
285                        return new Quartic(maxIterations, maxDelta, maxRad);
286                }
287                
288                // -----------------------------------------------------------
289                
290                @Override
291                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
292                        c[0] = s[0];
293                        c[1] = (s[1] - s[5]) / 2;
294                        c[2] = (s[7] - s[3]) / 2;
295                        c[3] = (s[1] - 2 * s[0] + s[5]) / 2;
296                        c[4] = (s[3] - 2 * s[0] + s[7]) / 2;
297                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
298                        c[6] = (-s[2] + 2 *s[3] - s[4] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 4;
299                        c[7] = (-2 * s[1] + s[2] - s[4] + 2 * s[5] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
300                        c[8] = s[0] + (-2 * s[1] + s[2] - 2 * s[3] + s[4] - 2 * s[5] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 4;
301                        
302                        // iteratively find the max location:
303                        boolean done = false;
304                        int n = 0;
305                        double[] xCur = {0, 0};
306                        double H00 = 0, H11 = 0, H01 = 0, d = 0;
307                        while (!done && n < maxIterations && normL2(xCur) < maxRad) {
308                                double[] g = this.getGradient(xCur);
309                                double[][] H = this.getHessian(xCur);
310                                H00 = H[0][0];
311                                H11 = H[1][1];
312                                H01 = H[0][1];
313                                d = H00 * H11 - sqr(H01);
314                                if (isZero(d)) {
315//                                      throw new RuntimeException(Quartic.class.getSimpleName() + ": zero determinant");
316                                        return null;
317                                }
318                                double[][] Hi = {                       // inverse Hessian
319                                                { H11 / d, -H01 / d}, 
320                                                {-H01 / d,  H00 / d}};  
321                                double[] xNext = add(xCur, multiply(multiply(-1, Hi), g));
322                                if (distL2(xCur, xNext) < maxDelta) {
323                                        done = true;
324                                }
325                                else {
326                                        xCur[0] = xNext[0];
327                                        xCur[1] = xNext[1];
328                                        n = n + 1;
329                                }
330                        }
331                        
332                        boolean isMax = (d > 0) && (H00 < 0);   // false if saddle point or relative minimum
333                        
334                        if (done && isMax) {
335                                float z = (float) getInterpolatedValue(xCur);
336                                return new float[] {(float) xCur[0], (float) xCur[1], z};
337                        }
338                        else {
339                                return null;
340                        }
341                }
342                
343                private double getInterpolatedValue(double[] X) {
344                        final double x = X[0];
345                        final double y = X[1];
346                        return c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y
347                                                + c[5]*x*y + c[6]*x*x*y + c[7]*x*y*y + c[8]*x*x*y*y;
348                }
349                
350                private double[] getGradient(double[] X) {
351                        return this.getGradient(X[0], X[1]);
352                }
353
354                private double[] getGradient(double x, double y) {
355                        double gx = c[1] + 2*c[3]*x + c[5]*y + 2*c[6]*x*y + c[7]*y*y + 2*c[8]*x*y*y;
356                        double gy = c[2] + c[5]*x + 2*c[4]*y + 2*c[7]*x*y + c[6]*x*x + 2*c[8]*x*x*y;
357                        return new double[] {gx, gy};
358                }
359                
360                private double[][] getHessian(double[] X) {
361                        return this.getHessian(X[0], X[1]);
362                }
363                
364                private double[][] getHessian(double x, double y) {
365                        final double H00 = 2*(c[3] + y*(c[6] + c[8]*y));
366                        final double H11 = 2*(c[4] + x*(c[7] + c[8]*x));
367                        final double H01 = c[5] + 2*c[6]*x + 2*c[7]*y + 4*c[8]*x*y;
368                        double[][] Hi = {
369                                        { H00, H01}, 
370                                        { H01, H11}};
371                        return Hi;
372                }
373                
374        }
375}
